I left my job in London to work with huskies in the Arctic Circle in Finland. I was 26 and felt restless. I wanted to experience the cold and quiet of the Arctic. I found a small company that takes tourists on sled rides pulled by huskies. They needed a new dog handler, so I joined them for three months.
I started packing immediately. On the plane, I looked at a list of over 100 husky names, but I was too nervous to memorize them. Instead, I looked out the window and saw the winter landscape. In Finland, the bus took me through dark forests and we stopped for reindeer to cross the road.
When I arrived at the farm, I was given a pair of boots and told to go outside. It was cold! Anna, my boss, asked if I wanted to start working right away. I followed the sound of barking dogs and saw people harnessing them to sleds. The dogs were excited and pulling hard. I introduced myself, but everyone was busy, so I just stood there and petted one of the dogs.
After a few days, I learned how to drive the sleds. It's easy: lean into the corners, use the brake, and hold the handlebar tight. But other tasks, like feeding and watering the dogs, were harder. The water would freeze in the cold weather, so we had to make a special soup for them.
At the end of my first week, I was tired and my muscles hurt. But I was proud of myself because I learned how to use an axe, hammer a nail, and use a saw in the snow.

Paula Radcliffe finished a marathon in an amazing time. The press were surprised because her time was good enough to qualify her for the men's marathon at the world championships. Reporters asked her about a special treatment she used, emu oil, which was recommended by Olympic gold medalist Cathy Freeman. Radcliffe had used it to help her heal from an injury she got when she ran into a bike while training.
Radcliffe said that she didn't really think about how amazing her achievement was at the time. She and her team had said they wouldn't set any limits for her, and she just focused on doing her best. Her coach and physiotherapist were with her during the race and were worried that she was going too fast. But Radcliffe was determined to push herself.
In the end, Radcliffe finished the race in under 2 hours and 16 minutes. She was very fast, but she thought she could go even faster. She was already thinking about next year's race and wanted to beat her time again.
People were surprised that Radcliffe, who had an unusual running style, was able to beat the East African runners who are known for their skill and grace. Her physiotherapist, Gerard Hartmann, worked with her for weeks at a time, helping her recover from her training. He said that Radcliffe was the hardest athlete he had ever worked with, and that she would often push him to his limits.
Radcliffe's record has not been beaten, and many women have been inspired to start running long distances because of her achievement.

I was surprised when my first cooking show, In Search of Perfection, was released. I wondered if people would like it because it was different from other cooking shows. It wasn't just about cooking techniques, but also about history, nostalgia, and science. I was a bit nervous when the first episode aired, but it was a success. This led to other projects, including a book about my restaurant. In each project, I went on a journey, whether it was into the past, into my own mind, or into the world of cooking.
I wrote several books called 'Perfection', each one accompanying a TV show of the same name. In these books, I traveled to different places to learn about food and cooking. In the latest book, In Search of Total Perfection, I traveled the world to meet people who are passionate about their work, like a man who makes golden pasta that tastes amazing. These people have spent years trying to achieve their idea of perfection.
Perfection is a personal thing, and it's hard to agree on what's perfect. Even choosing which dishes to include in the book was difficult, and I knew I would upset some people by leaving out their favorite dishes. But we managed to come up with a list that everyone could agree on.
In the book, I use my technical skills and scientific knowledge to understand what makes certain dishes work. I also talk to food producers, artisans, and chefs to learn from them. The dictionary defines perfection as being perfect, but also as trying and testing until you get it right. This book is about my journey to find perfection in food, and it's not about claiming that my recipes are the only perfect ones.

We were still far from Marrakech when our van broke down in a field. John got out to look at the engine, but he didn't know what was wrong. He and my mum started laughing. My sister Bea was worried. 'We can't stay here forever,' she said. The field was big and empty, with just grass and flowers. 'We can't stay here forever,' I repeated, because it's always better to agree with Bea.
We got back in the van and waited for John to find someone who could fix the car. Mum lay down on the grass and said, 'Tell us a story.' My sister and I sat down next to her. I told them about the birds I heard talking in London before we left. I told them what they were talking about, like breadcrumbs and the weather. My sister didn't believe me. She said, 'That's stupid, no one understands bird language.' I felt sad.
After a while, John came back with some Moroccan boys who helped us push the van to a nearby hotel. My sister didn't want to get out, but the boys didn't mind. They waved at her through the window. We followed John to the hotel café. It was a nice place with a shady area where we could sit. We had tea made from mint leaves, which was very sweet. My mum said it was like syrup.
We stayed at the café all day while John tried to fix the car. When it started getting dark, John said, 'I think it's a miracle we made it this far.' My mum made a bed for us on the road, and we slept there. The next day, John said we would have to have the van towed to Marrakech. We rode in a truck, watching our van being pulled behind us. My sister didn't want to move at first, but John picked her up and put her in the truck. Now she was sitting in the front with the driver. I was worried about how we would get back home with our broken van. I thought it might be easier if we could take a boat to London. Then I fell asleep.

Lucy was talking to two other pianists at a party in a big hotel ballroom. One was a man from Tokyo and the other was a woman from a European city. They were both older than Lucy and could speak English well. They talked about the music they played, where they had been, and where they were going next. Lucy mentioned that she was going to the Tanglewood festival. The man from Tokyo was surprised and asked how old she was. Lucy said she was 15.
Lucy didn't really want to go to the festival, but her mom had sent in an application without asking her. Lucy's mom thought it would be good for her, but Lucy felt like her mom was trying to control her. Lucy didn't want to go to the festival, but she didn't want to say no to her mom either.
At the party, Lucy met some other people and talked to them. She met a man from Tokyo who had long hair and asked her if she had been to Japan. Lucy said she had been there when she was 8. Then, Lucy's grandfather came and took her away to talk to some important people. Lucy smiled and nodded, but didn't really listen to what they were saying.
After the party, Lucy's grandfather told her that she did a good job and that people knew who she was. Lucy liked being famous, even if some people were jealous of her. She didn't get respect from her friends at school, but at places like this, she felt important.

'My dad says I spend too much time online and I should get out more. But I wanted to know what experts think. Most teenagers who use social media have many friends, a good sense of who they are, and learn important skills. Simon Miles, an expert on online safety, says social media is just a part of modern life for teenagers. It's not good or bad - it depends on how we use it.
Jim Matthews, a social media analyst, says social media is like a virtual youth club. It helps teenagers make friends, share jokes, and talk about their interests. It's like the way our parents used to hang out at the youth club when they were our age.
Psychologist Professor Keith Davidson says social media can help us figure out who we are and what we like. We can post about our favorite things and see what others like. Research shows that people who use social media a lot are not as self-centered as those who don't.
Professor Andrew Phillips says social media can be helpful for shy people or those with special interests. They can connect with others who like the same things. Pauline White, an expert on digital education, says social media can be a creative force. Teenagers can make videos, podcasts, and blogs about things they're interested in. They can also share photos and learn from others.
She thinks social media will be important in the workplace. Every business uses social media to sell products and increase brand awareness. Teenagers who use social media creatively will have an advantage when they grow up and start working.'

When most people think of a family vacation, they don't usually think of a big road trip across nine states in the US and one province in Canada. But my parents planned our summer vacation this way. They wanted to do something special and different. My dad seemed to think it would be fun for my twin brother and me to spend two weeks together in the car. We were not so sure.
We packed our bags and set off on our adventure. We drove through the Oklahoma panhandle, where we saw a huge dust storm. We learned that cows have the right of way on the roads! The next day, we drove to the mountains and then to a place called Pagosa Springs in Colorado. The air smelled of sulfur, which was interesting.
We hiked in the sand dunes and visited a town called Four Corners, where we saw a big sign that said "CLOSED". We also saw many wind farms and drove through Yellowstone National Park, where we saw bears and had to wait for them to cross the road. We even had a close encounter with a bear!
After a while, we stayed in a hotel with no internet or phone signal. It was old and creaky, but we loved the views. We watched a rainstorm from our window and felt happy. When it was time to go home, we were sad to leave, but we were also happy to have had such a great adventure together. We took many photos and will always remember the fun we had.

Rose Frost was 16 years old and was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Rose's parents were separating and would be living abroad for two years. Her sister Amy would stay in England and live with the college Head while finishing her school courses. Rose would live with Daisy, who had offered to take care of her. Rose's parents were not very keen on the idea, but Daisy was happy to have Rose stay with her.
Rose hadn't seen her grandmother much before, but she remembered happy times with her. Daisy was a lively person who liked to socialize and have fun. Rose was looking forward to living with her and doing things her own way. She wanted to be able to play music loudly, invite friends over, and go out without needing permission all the time.
Rose's parents and grandmother had talked about this and agreed that Rose would have more freedom. They would trust her to make good choices and Rose would trust Daisy not to be too bossy. Rose had always been a responsible student and had good grades, so this was a good opportunity for her to grow up and become more independent.
In a few weeks, Rose would start a new school and make new friends. This would be her fourth school in five years, but she was excited to start her final two years of school. Rose saw this as a new chapter in her life, a new piece of the puzzle that was her life.

Charlotte Grainger wrote a book when she was 15 years old. Her teacher thought she might write a book when she was older, but Charlotte decided to try when she was 13. Her book is about to be published. She wrote it because she enjoyed reading and wanted to try something new.
The book is about a girl who is brave and takes responsibility. Charlotte thinks that some books about teenagers are not very good because they show them as being weak or silly. She wanted to write a book that showed a strong and capable teenager.
Charlotte likes to read fantasy books, but they made her feel like she couldn't write a good book. She liked a book called How Not to Write a Novel, which told her to make the story surprising so the reader doesn't guess what will happen.
Charlotte's parents are journalists, and they helped her get her book published. She thinks that getting someone to read her book is hard, but after that, it's up to the writer to make it good. She is grateful for her good luck, but she also knows that writers have to work hard to be successful.

We went to a ski resort in the US to learn freestyle skiing. Our instructor, Gareth, told us that speed is important, but we should be careful. One of our group, David, went first and tried a big jump. He didn't do well and fell. Gareth reminded us that speed can be unpredictable.
I had never done freestyle skiing before. In the past, I had just enjoyed skiing slowly and making turns. I thought freestyle skiing looked fun, but I was worried that I wouldn't be good at it. When we got to the resort, we practiced on trampolines and ski jumps with artificial snow. We even had foam cubes to land in if we fell.

Imagine you're on a rollercoaster in an amusement park. Your heart is racing and you're feeling scared. The ride stops, then goes up slowly. Then, it drops quickly and you feel like you're flying. The ride is very fast and you're screaming. But you knew what you were getting yourself into when you paid to go to the theme park.
It's surprising that amusement parks are so popular. They have many people working behind the scenes to make the rides exciting and safe. These people are engineers and designers who are very good at their jobs. They make sure the rides are fun, but not too scary.
Designing a rollercoaster is a big job. It's not just about making the ride go up and down. It's about making it exciting and safe at the same time. The designers have to think about what the riders will like and how to make the ride feel new and exciting every time.
I talked to three experts who design rollercoasters. They said that the key is to make the ride feel exciting, but not too scary. They have to balance the ups and downs of the ride to make it feel like a thrilling experience. They also have to create a story for the ride, like a space adventure or a jungle chase, to make it feel like a complete experience.
The experts also talked about how they test the rides before they open to the public. They have to make sure the ride is safe and fun. They also have to be a little bit thrill-seekers themselves to understand what riders want.
I asked them if they think rollercoasters will change with new technology, like virtual reality. One of the experts said that while new technology can add to the ride experience, the physical coaster experience will always be the most important part.

Miranda Ellington is a 25-year-old choreographer who has already worked with many theatres and dance companies. She also still dances sometimes. I'm curious to know why she does both. She says that being a dancer again reminds her of the challenges of being a dancer and how frustrating it can be. As a choreographer, she enjoys teaching young students. They are open to new ideas and willing to take risks. She likes working with students because they are eager to learn and don't have a fixed idea of what they can or can't do.
When Miranda starts working with a new group, she focuses on the dance steps and the music. Sometimes she doesn't like the music, but she still creates a good dance routine. If the dancers don't like the music, it can be frustrating, but she has to find a solution. She would like to be able to choose different music, but that's not always possible.
Miranda doesn't like to work with just one theatre or school. She likes to work with different people and adapt her style to fit each place. She believes that this helps her stay creative and not get stuck in a routine.
I ask her about a recent documentary about professional ballet dancers and choreographers. She thinks it's a good portrayal of the hard work and dedication required to be a professional dancer. She says that a great dance production is when everything comes together - the music, costumes, lighting, and dancers. She believes that aiming high is important, even if it's not perfect.
I ask her if she sees herself as a modern dance choreographer or a ballet specialist. She says that people like to put labels on things, but she doesn't like to be limited to one style. She wants to keep exploring and trying new things.
